body:
i used to compile mxnet with CUDA 8.0 RC  cudnn 5.1 opencv 3.0  mkl in windows 10 and had the this problem too
now, i change  CUDA 8.0 RC to CUDA 8.0 and find no problem
P.S i use gtx 1060
what's your cuda and gcc version

The problem is existing models use -1 for global reduction and it's written into the json files.

@tqchen We need a versioning and conversion system for json files
you need to set LD_LIBRARY_PATH properly

@piiswrong: for some reason the Scala fails, despite me changing no Scala code. It gives error:

> No output has been received in the last 10m0s, this potentially indicates a stalled build or something wrong with the build itself.
I think we will change the convention of sum to allow tuple axis first and none. The negative index support could come later after 0.9 get widely adopted

gcc version 5.4.0 20160609 (Ubuntu 5.4.0-6ubuntu1~16.04.2) 
Cuda compilation tools, release 7.5, V7.5.17
Either way we need versioning and conversion to change axis=-1 to axis=None for previously saved jsons

# My osx.mk file is:

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS =  -D_FORCE_INLINES

# My Makefile is

CFLAGS = -D_MWAITXINTRIN_H_INCLUDED

cuda doesn't support gcc 5.x
Try downgrade to 4.8
I have no problem compiling with cuda-8.0/cudnn-5.1 and gcc-5.4 on ubuntu 16.04. No need to downgrade to 4.8.

@piiswrong checkpoint saving and loading is already supported for plain `Module`. For example, the built-in `checkpoint` callback works fine in the same way. I think @bearsroom is talking about more complicated modules like `SequentialModule` and `BucketingModule`. In some cases, there are multiple symbols (like bucketing). I was thinking about saving all the instantiated instances as a key-value dictionary. But that might not be enough during testing. In some other cases, such a `PythonModule`, there might not even be any symbol associated with it.

Currently a better solution might be to isolate the network definition functions of your experiment in a separate file, and load that file to define networks in both training and testing, and then it will work even if no symbols are loaded. But I agree this is not ideal for deploying.
@gengyifeng Your error was due to the front-end python package not getting updated.
@feiyulv It is already been added to NNVM branch
please put all imaegs and pdfs in dmlc/web-data
Is it possible to implement the scale operator via broadcast multiply? I feel that Scale is a quite generic name that need to be carefully thinked before merge it in
please rebase the change against latest nnvm
I think the general idea was to avoid kv.rank in single machine training. Maybe consider only add it when number of kv nodes is bigger than 1? @mli
i think it is a good idea to add `-%d % (kv.rank)` only if kv.rank > 0

looks like amalgamation's problem
@glingyan While you are at it, could you also fix the warnings caused by mkl?
Its a hyperparameter that you can set to whatever you want.
seems like your opencv is not properly installed
how about put this three c++ operator in the main mxnet/src/operator, so that it can be checked during mxnet update, and it may used in other detection project.

@amitkb3 The code assume training and testing file were segmented. line 41 in the `data_helpers.py` we use space as separator. In line 122 we use `build_vocab` to prepare vocabulary, notice that variable `sentences_padded` is a list of words.
`git submodule update`

Thanks, @piiswrong @glingyan
Updated, it looks like the amalgamation.py problem: it doesn't filter the mkl2017 .h file
change amalgamation.py  line 89-90 to:

```
if not source:
    if h not in blacklist and h not in sysheaders and 'mkl' not in h: sysheaders.append(h)
```

fixed the error!

@blazerygy It's a linux problem not mxnet. I think the followed command may work for you.
`export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/cuda/lib64:/home/ygy/cudnn/cuda_cudnn5.0/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`

@pluskid  Saving and loading params using `load_params` and `save_params` in `Module` works fine for me, but I was thinking about another advantage of having a complete definition of network: We can easily check every component and visualize the network using `mxnet.visualization` (it requires symbol definitions too!). Also it's more straightforward for caffe people, as the whole network is well defined in a single prototxt file.

These aren't generic enough. I think either put it in example or in plugin

I did not mean the absolute value of batch size. I mean what the batch size should be when using multiple GPUs compared to the batch size when using only 1 GPU. For example, when using 1 GPU, we set the batch size as M. If the goal is just to see the performance speedup when using multiple GPUs, then for the same model using 2 GPUs, the batch size should also be M instead of 2M, right? Because if we use 2M, then the learning will be different from M. 

In GoogleNet, I did use M (M=64) for 1 GPU and multiple GPUs and got good speedup. But for Inception-BN, I had to use M for 1 GPU and 2M for 2 GPUs. That's the part I do not understand.

I saw an error in libdc1394 from https://github.com/szilard/benchm-dl/blob/master/cnn-mnist/2a-mxnet-run.txt#L88

This is an opencv error, can you try the solution in http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12689304/ctypes-error-libdc1394-error-failed-to-initialize-libdc1394 and rerun the script?
`sudo ln /dev/null /dev/raw1394` fixed the libdc1394 warning, but the above error still the same. I'm trying to see if I can make the error go away if I take out bits of code.
Btw the error appears only when I quit R, so all the code runs (seems to run) OK.
Can you try `detach("package:mxnet", unload=TRUE)` before the quit?


The error goes away if I take out Dropout.
I use the -1 trick, which MXNet would auto-figureout batchsize. Take a look at the document for details.

@piiswrong Backward inherit from ConvolutionOp, Forward use fast algorithm of NNPACK.
NNPACK support ARMv7/ARM64, embedded devices may benefit from this code.

tests/python/predict/mxnet_predict_example.py

| OPENMP | NNPACK thread=1 | NNPACK thread=2 | NNPACK thread=4 | MXNET conv |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| OFF | 0.395s | 0.323s | 0.290s | 0.402s |

conv test result:

| input | f | k | s | NNPACK t=1 | t=2 | t=4 | MXNET conv | speedup |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 3x1000x1000 | 28 | 9x9 | 1x1 | 0.739s | 0.521s | 0.441s | 4.01s | 9.1x |
| 20x600x600 | 20 | 5x5 | 1x1 | 0.234s | 0.176s | 0.151s | 2.76s | 18x |
| 3x600x600 | 32 | 5x5 | 1x1 | 0.188s | 0.146s | 0.129s | 0.569s | 4.4x |
| 128x60x60 | 128 | 5x5 | 1x1 | 0.0533s | 0.0340s | 0.0254s | 0.168s | 6.6x |
| 3x60x60 | 3 | 5x5 | 1x1 | 0.00123s | 0.00134s | 0.00210s | 0.00469s | 2.2x |
| 3x60x60 | 3 | 3x3 | 1x1 | 0.00118s | 0.00114s | 0.00145s | 0.00242s | 1.6x |

conv test code:

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import os, sys, time
import numpy as np

data = mx.sym.Variable("data")
net = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=28, kernel=(9, 9), stride=(1,1), pad=(0,0))

mod = mx.mod.Module(symbol=net)
mod.bind(data_shapes=[("data" , (1,3,1000,1000))], for_training=False, inputs_need_grad=False)
mod.init_params()

d = np.ones((1,3,1000,1000))
start = time.time()
dataiter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(d)
r = mod.predict(dataiter).asnumpy()
print 'time: ' , (time.time() - start)

```

OS : Centos7.2
Software: CaffeOnSpark
if you want to use atlas, Please modified the caffe-public/Makefile, cblas -> satlas , atlas -> tatlas ,
and you also modified the caffe-distribute/Makefile , cblas -> satlas, atlas -> tatlas.
run this comand

```
make clean
make build
```

will fix this bug !

@tqchen It requires the scaling factors to be learning through BP(across channel or across spatial), not just a single layer-wise scalar.
Sure you can hack it with a conv layers with multiply(with groups of filters maybe?), but I don't like groups of filters neither, you cannot decide how many groups when designing a network(in this case spatial dimension related).

But you are right, this name is so generic. Just wonder why such a simple operator haven't been added.
In the meantime, I will rename it and put into example directory.

The operator does exist, it's called broadcast mul

@tqchen 
I can come up with some idea, but questionable:

```
# suppose convx has a shape (32, 256, 16, 16)
# cross spatial scale shape can be decided
scale = mx.sym.Variable(name='convx_scale', shape=(1, nchannel, 1, 1))
# cross channel scale, don't know the spatial info here:
scale = mx.sym.Variable(name='convx_scale', shape=(1, 1, width, height))

scale_out = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(lhs=scale, rhs=convx, name='broadcast_scale_out')
```

I suspect this won't work since at least two dimensions don't match(for scale, batch-size always 1, for data, it varies)

broadcast_mul works the same ways as numpy's broadcasting. This should work
